projects.name: Restructuring a foundry
projects.description: TTS Polak, the aluminum foundry of Festool, had been loosing millions since its integration into the TTS group. The situation worsened after new large investments, draining considerable cash and management resources for a none-core business, exhausting 3 managing directors in just 4 years.
keyProblems: High resignation of staff and management
Unsustainable drive towards output with quality far beyond industry standard
Unprofitable customer mix
keySolutions: Simplified organizational structure and pay schemes, clarified decision process to reinforce accountability and front-line initiative
Put emphasis of quality (new bonus system), advocated sustainability before quantity by rewarding continuous improvement initiative
Renegotiated customer contracts (price increases, production face-out) incl. automotive Tier1-suppliers whilst pushing for a customer diversification in non-automotive segment
projects.output: TTS Polak became cash flow positive after 12 months and reached the break-even after 18 months. This enabled the selling of the company to a strategic investor whilst remaining supplier for the former owner.
lesson: Importance of local leadership presence
Inter arma enim silent leges, the need of restructuring specific structures and processes
Cultural differences in payment schemes
projects.alt: A picture of the production site of the TTS Polak

projects.name: Winning an iconic global player as a customer
projects.description: A major Scandinavian manufacturer of exclusive music and television systems, well known for its iconic design, was looking for a new foundry nearer to its production site in CZ.
keyProblems: Unclear underlying customer requirements
Fear-driven decision process (possible bankruptcy of previous supplier)
High technological requirements with limited knowledge<
keySolutions: Challenged customer's requirements at board level to place technological support, quality and availability before saving
Positioned ourselves as partners, explaining the consequences of the impetuous actions, helping the customer in budgeting the costs of such a program and preparing a fall-back plan
Set up a dedicated support team for this customer, which meets the customer's designers for feasibility workshops on quarterly basis
projects.output: The customer chose Benes a Lat as a single-source supplier not just for aluminum but also for zinc parts and a large amount of its plastic elements. The transition process took a 2 year period to ensure a manageable workload and limited one-time expenses. This ensures a high customer satisfaction and multi-million revenue per year at quite satisfying margins.
lesson: Importance of challenging the customer in the sales process
Organization of a multi-level sales strategy
projects.alt: A video displaying Benes a Lat's production capacities, largely in low pressure die casting

projects.name: Selling a foundry admits its restructuring
projects.description: Selling a company is always an exciting project. Selling the company whilst restructuring it brings everything to a higher dimension. You can add additional factors, such as a high dependence from the selling company on delivered parts
keyProblems: Different priorities within the selling entity
Limited corporate resource allocation
Necessity of keeping top performers on board
keySolutions: Clarified and validated a ranked list of expectations with the supervisory board of the selling company
Set up a team of external consultants (lawyers, M&A consultant) and internal resources under my direct leadership
Informed the key players early and offered them alternative scenarios
projects.output: TTS Polak was sold to a strategic investor to the satisfaction of all parties: the schedule was largely kept, the supply of products was guaranteed, the staff was largely left untouched
lesson: Importance of clear priorities
Avoid the shell shock: continue with your strategy! As long as it is reasonable, it will create value.
projects.alt: A picture of one casting cell at TTS Polak

projects.name: Design a master data management system
projects.description:
Software is eating the world - M. Andreesen. And software feeds on data. So companies need to structure their data via a master data management system to leverage data as a real corporate asset.

In the past having well structured data helped you to save IT costs. Now it enables the use of big data, of (contact/product/...) mass customization, of Internet of the Things... It simply enables of the Future
keyProblems: No common understanding of concepts between departments and legal entity
Unclear vision about current maturity level
keySolutions: Gathered and interviewed key users throughout the corporate organization
Audited the company following IBM Data Governance framework
projects.output: The audit showed the need to develop a data steward organization, similar to SW key user. These experienced business users will then discuss, define and document the data and its interpretation and closely monitor the implementation by the IT department and the legal entities.
lesson: Data is too important and valuable to be left in the single care of the IT department
Master Data Management is a heavy but healthy process to follow
You don't need to start big, but you need to start fast
projects.alt: A presentation video of Festool and its core values

projects.name: Building the foundations for a FabLab
projects.description:
In today's world design and production of small scale innovative products are no longer a challenge. Digital production capabilities (3d printing, CNC-machining, ...) allows you to move at previously unknown pace and costs. Furthermore this equipment can be shared with liked-minded individuals in a makerspace or a FabLab.
And please be conscious that it is not just for after-work, companies can use it to leverage skill acquisition, employee loyalty and innovation potential.
keyProblems: Lack of understanding the concept
Unclear expectations
Fear of its implications (agile development, shared economics, ... )
keySolutions: Explained the idea and proposed several implementation scenarios
Advocated for a clear mission statement with board endorsements
Proposed several implementation concepts
projects.output: Festool's COO and his team were persuaded to launch a FabLab in its facilities. When I handed over the concepts for implementation, the expectations were set, the way clear. Now time will show whether it will be accepted by the organization.
lesson: The immense potential of digital production capabilities
The tremendous potential of agile development and collaborative methods, ...
... but also their disruptive effects on an organizational structure
projects.alt: Illustration of a Fablab, De Waag Society, Amsterdam, picture by Rory Hyde

projects.name: Restructuring a finance departement
projects.description:
AVL France was the enfant terrible of the AVL group: the budget always looked bright (with a small profit). Then hope declined forecast after forecast... and finally 1 mio€ equity needed to be injected each year on average.
It is easy to blame the finance department. A possible solution was to try to get more clarity with an SAP implementation. And when this failed, there was no other option but restructuring the department.
keyProblems: Unclear responsibilities between departments (accounting, order processing, controlling)
Inability to meet deadlines (monthly closing at months+20days instead of months+5 days
Lack of recognition by the remaining management team
keySolutions: Clarified the job descriptions and expectations, implemented a clear reporting line
Draw the closing process, identified the gaps and improved the process (e.g. a good estimate in 10 min is better than the precise figure 3 weeks later)
Positioned the department as a business partner (moved the team from their offices to the front-lines, asked a lot, offered a business perspective, challenged the views)
projects.output:
In 2009 AVL France halved its losses. In 2010 AVL France was around break-even. In 2011 it made the first profit in 15 years.
The strong collaboration between the service and the finance departments enabled the former to double its revenues to 4 mio€ and moved its margin from disastrous -20% to record-breaking +25%.

Moreover the finance department became one of the group's benchmarks: monthly closing in 2 days, full-IFRS year-end closing (incl. IAS 11 & 18 valuation and documentation) in 6 days, ...
lesson: IFRS balancing
Importance of the strong financial process and knowledge of the main hurdles
projects.alt: An automotive test bed from AVL

projects.name: Building an automated reporting system
projects.description:
AVL Europe was freshly founded as one of three major regions. A regional VP was nominated, business unit managers hired, yet the colleagues had no reporting to monitor the performance of their units.
The challenge was to grant a good view for the European structure, without adding additional administrative (unproductive) work for these units.
keyProblems: Large amount of reporting already prepared by the legal entities
High expectations from European team
Low acceptance from both local entities and head quarter
keySolutions: Used extensively existing reports (no additional requests)
Introduced highly graphical reports
Emphasized on high automation
projects.output: A whole set of new management tools were developed in a couple of months. The aim was to avoid the same work on several hierarchical levels. A special focus was set on a high degree of automation, as controlling employees should not be there to edit reports, but to extract their insights. The reports were improved over time in order to become more and more predictive.
lesson: Aim for respectful efficiency: do not have the job done twice!
Share the insights and automated pattern recognition
projects.alt: A video about AVL's capacities, especially with the new digital solution

projects.name: Rebuilding a finance department
projects.description:
AGT Thermotechnik was my first job after finishing my studies at the WHU and getting my master at Audencia. And what a start!
The company was freshly acquired by the TTS group and was not really wanted: it came with the real target and as it was an important supplier of the latter, TTS kept it. However it was a money-losing entity.
The management decided to renew the finance staff by hiring a new finance manager, but the remaining finance team resigned within days.
keyProblems: Absence of accountants and large booking backlog
Very tight cash situation
Erroneous balance sheet
keySolutions: Took over the accounting personally (from textbook directly to single bookings)
Set up a cash flow management
projects.output:
AGT had a restructured finance department and clean books at my departure.
It was a tough experience: I learned accounting and cash flow management the hard way and I am grateful for this!
lesson: Accounting in general and HGB (German GAAP) in particular
High sensitivity for balance sheet analysis
There are compliance rules and compliance rules (Sarbanes Oxley and German Mittelständler might not be compatible)
projects.alt: the gas samplers produced by AGT

projects.name: Changing paradigms, Building a Loss Report
projects.description:
IBM set up ibm.com in the early 2000s in order to keep DELL at bay. This unit was selling principally via phone and internet, focusing on covering the market, identifying the leads and forwarding them to the suitable sales organization or business partner.
The aim of sales operations was to help the sales team in providing analysis, reporting and budgeting. The prevalent idea was that you would need more leads to generate more sales.
But why didn't the revenue rise with an increasing pipeline? Was there an optimum lead generation? Was the unit beyond it?
keyProblems: Plenty of CRM data available, but unsorted
a single focus on winning deals
keySolutions: Developed a data analysis tool via Hyperion
Automated its publishing
projects.output:
There was indeed an optimum after which the best tactic becomes lose less (leads) to gain more (revenue). The approach was new for IBM and the report was adopted in EMEA. Though it was not widely adopted for its largest paradigm, it became used for specific sets of problems (weakness of a segment, of a product line), becoming more a marketing than a sales management tool.

This report challenging current opinions was rewarded with an IBM bravo award, a nearly unique recognition for an intern.
lesson: Challenge paradigms!
Big data is crucial (and not that scary)!
projects.alt: An IBM commercial from the time of the project, which suits it well

projects.name: Renegotiating all automotive contracts
projects.description:
The world of die casting is divided in two main segments: automotive and (non-automotive) industry. Both worlds do have their own requirements. The short version would be that it is easier to get an automotive contract and far harder to earn money and vice versa. Moreover you need to specialize your processes for one or the other. Whilst you can have 30% of automotive business (it offers you a baseline, a good drill) and still aim for the industry business, having a larger share might be quite unhealthy.
TTS Polak had a 60% automotive share in 2011, yet a shareholder and largest customer in the industry segment. So the strategic choice might have been obvious: focus on industry business, especially as the automotive business was loss-making. The contracts with the three main automotive suppliers needed to be renegotiated.
keyProblems: Unclear legal status
Unknown position of the customers
keySolutions: Analyzed each situation with an internal and external team
Focused first on possible relationship improvements, stroke later when opportune
projects.output: Separate solutions were found. The major supplier accepted 10 to 15% price increase after seeing the improvements in quality and product deliveries. We found a smooth phase-out solution with the smallest customer. Only one customer challenged the decision and claimed 500-600 k€ in damages. The final agreement was 1/15th of this amount and represented the remaining warranty.
lesson: Don't be scared by the automotive segment.
Take your time to negotiate and move step by step!
projects.alt: A mirror holder for a utility car produced at Bal z08 (formerly TTS Polak)
